elements.content: Three novel organic−inorganic hybrid materials with mixed 4,4‘-bipyridine and 2,2‘-bipyridine ligands, K[{CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}(4,4‘-bipy){CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}0.5]2[Mo8O26] (1), [CuI(4,4‘-bipy)]3[PMo10 VIMo2 VO40{CuII(2,2‘-bipy)}] (2), and [CuI(2,2‘-bipy)(4,4‘-bipy)0.5]2[CuI(4,4‘-bipy)]2[SiW12O4 0] (3) (2,2‘-bipy = 2,2‘-bipyridine, 4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine), have been hydrothermally synthesized. Compound 1 is a novel β-[Mo8O26]4- polyoxoanion bisupported by copper(I) coordination cations with mixed 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy ligands. Compound 2 consists of the divalent copper {CuII(2,2‘-bipy)}2+ capped [PMo10 VIMo2 VO40]5- building blocks linked by {Cu(4,4‘-bipy)} n n + linear cationic chains into a novel two-dimensional (2D) network. To the best of our knowledge, compound 2 exhibits an unprecedented 2D structure containing the divalent copper capped polyoxometalate as building blocks. The novel structure of 3 is composed of one-dimensional hybrid zigzag chains linked by {Cu(4,4‘-bipy)} n n + chains into a three-dimensional (3D) framework via weak Cu−O interactions. The novelty of compound 3 is that it is the first time that a novel 3D framework has been formed by polyoxometalate and transition metal coordination polymer chains with mixed 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy.

elements.content: Three novel organic−inorganic materials with mixed 4,4‘-bipyridine and 2,2‘-bipyridine, K[{CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}(4,4‘-bipy){CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}0.5]2[Mo8O26] (1), [CuI(4,4‘-bipy)]3[PMo10 VIMo2 VO40{CuII(2,2‘-bipy)}] (2), and [CuI(2,2‘-bipy)(4,4‘-bipy)0.5]2[CuI(4,4‘-bipy)]2[SiW12O40] (3) (2,2‘-bipy = 2,2‘-bipyridine, 4,4‘-bipy = 4,4‘-bipyridine), have been hydrothermally prepared. Compound 1 is a novel bisupported isopolyoxomolybdate with mixed ligands, and to the best of our knowledge, compound 2 represents the first two-dimensional structure containing the divalent copper capped polyoxometalate building blocks, which crystallized in a chiral space group P21.

elements.content: The rapid progress of exploring organic−inorganic hybrid materials is driven by the interest of their structural diversity and fascinating properties with applications to catalysis, ion exchange, sorption, magnetism, electrical conductivity, and photochemistry. The evolution of organic−inorganic hybrid materials is dependent upon the synthesis of new solids possessing unique structures and properties, although the synthetic design of such materials remains a challenge in solid-state chemistry. One approach for the design of organic−inorganic hybrid materials is to introduce some interesting transition-metal complexes, which serve as organic−inorganic bridging ligands, into the covalent backbone of inorganic oxides. The transition−metal complexes can dramatically influence the inorganic oxides microstructure, and a series of novel organic−inorganic hybrid materials have been found.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rapid progress of exploring organic-inorganic hybrid materials is driven by the interest of their structural diversity and fascinating properties with applications to catalysis, ion exchange, sorption, magnetism, electrical conductivity, and photochemistry. The evolution of organic-inorganic hybrid materials is dependent upon the synthesis of new solids possessing unique structures and properties, although the synthetic design of such materials remains a challenge in solid-state chemistry. One approach for the design of organic-inorganic hybrid materials is to introduce some interesting transition-metal complexes, which serve as organic-inorganic bridging ligands, into the covalent backbone of inorganic oxides. The transition-metal complexes can dramatically influence the inorganic oxides microstructure, and a series of novel organic-inorganic hybrid materials have been found.

elements.content: Meanwhile, polyoxometalates (POMs), as an important family of metal oxides, because of their diverse topological properties and great potential applications in catalysis, photochemistry, medicine, and magnetism, are an outstanding class of inorganic building blocks for the design and construction of organic−inorganic hybrid materials with various transition metal complexes as bridging ligands. What is more important, POMs have capabilities similar to organic ligands to coordinate to metal centers to achieve its combination with a metal−organic skeleton and to display various discrete structures of definite nanoscopic sizes. Therefore, the functionality of organic−inorganic hybrid materials based on POMs can be multiplied by the incorporation of inorganic and organic counterparts into one structural unit.
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, polyoxometalates (POMs), as an important family of metal oxides, because of their diverse topological properties and great potential applications in catalysis, photochemistry, medicine, and magnetism, are an outstanding class of inorganic building blocks for the design and construction of organic-inorganic hybrid materials with various transition metal complexes as bridging ligands. What is more important, POMs have capabilities similar to organic ligands to coordinate to metal centers to achieve its combination with a metal-organic skeleton and to display various discrete structures of definite nanoscopic sizes. Therefore, the functionality of organic-inorganic hybrid materials based on POMs can be multiplied by the incorporation of inorganic and organic counterparts into one structural unit.

elements.content: Furthermore, it is expected that novel structures can be synthesized by introducing mixed ligands into the POMs system. For example, Chen's group prepared a novel polycatenated double-layered hybrid organic−inorganic material [Zn2(tp)(4,4‘-bipy)V2O6] (tp = terepthalate), containing vanadium oxides and mixed organoamine and dicarboxylate ligands. The most curious feature of [Cu(4,4‘-bipy)(nic)(H2O)]2Mo8O26 (nic = nicotinic acid)6b is that the extended structure is composed of an interpenetrated arrangement of two kinds of multizigzag chain polymers entangled together. Liu and co-workers reported the compound [Co(en)2][Co(2,2'-bipy)2]2[PMoVI 5MoV 3VIV 8O44]·4.5H2O (en = ethylenediamine), which is the first example of a 2D framework where polyoxoanions are linked by two types of complex fragments. More recently, an unusual one-dimensional (1D) chainlike material [4,4‘-Hbipy][{Cu2(2,2‘-bipy)2(4,4‘-bipy)2.5}PW11CuO39]·6H2O6d with a mixture of 2,2‘-bipy and 4,4‘-bipy has been characterized by the Dolbecq group. As part of our continuing efforts in the construction of organic−inorganic hybrid materials, our group synthesized a novel three-dimensional (3D) copper molybdate [CuII(2,2‘-bipy)CuII(IN)2Mo4O12(OH)2] with mixed ligands 2,2‘-bipy and nicotinic acid, and more recently we have exploited mixed 4,4‘-bipy and 1,10‘-phen ligands to synthesize an unusual 3D host−guest framework, [Cu3 ICl(4,4‘-bipy)4][CuII(1,10-phen)2Mo8O26], with a 1D organic−inorganic hybrid polyoxometalate chain as template. We can see the mixed ligands in these compounds are usually organoamine and dicarboxylate ligands, or two chelating organoamine ligands, but it is rare with one linear organoamine and one chelating organoamine ligands. Inspired by the aforementioned considerations, the remarkable bidentate ligands, 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy, first seized our attention because of the following considerations:  (1) The linear rigid 4,4‘-bipy ligand contains two terminal pyridyl group in the opposite position, which has been explored in constructing extended structures, especially in the POMs field. For example, Zubieta, Haushalter, and co-workers reported the first 1D organic−inorganic hybrid, [{Cu(4,4‘-bipy)}4Mo8O26], using {Cu(4,4‘-bipy)} n n + chains and polyoxometalates as building blocks. (2) The noticeable chelating 2,2‘-bipy ligand also presents a structural versatility. Therefore, intriguing structures are expected to be synthesized by introducing the 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy ligands into a single structure. Herein we report three novel organic−inorganic hybrid materials with mixed 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy ligands:  K[{CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}(4,4‘-bipy){CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}0.5]2[Mo8O26] (1), [CuI(4,4‘-bipy)]3[PMo10 VIMo2 VO40{CuII(2,2‘-bipy)}] (2), and [CuI(2,2‘-bipy)(4,4‘-bipy)0.5]2[CuI(4,4‘-bipy)]2[SiW12O40] (3). Compound 1 is a novel bisupported β-[Mo8O26]4- cluster with mixed ligands. The unusual 2D structure of compound 2 is constructed from the polyoxometalate clusters with divalent first-row transition metal as capping atoms and transition metal coordination polymer chains {Cu(4,4‘-bipy)} n n +. To the best of our knowledge, compound 2 represents the first example of a 2D structure containing the divalent copper capped polyoxometalate building blocks. Compound 3 has an unusual 3D structure constructed from 1D hybrid zigzag chains linked by {Cu(4,4‘-bipy)} n n + chains via weak Cu−O interactions.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental analyzer. Mo, W, Si, P, and Cu were determined by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded in the range of 400−4000 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN Elemental analyzer. Mo, W, Si, P, and Cu were determined by a Leaman inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectrometer. The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrophotometer with pressed KBr pellets.

elements.content: Synthesis of Compound 1 − 3. Synthesis of Compound 1. A mixture of KF (0.017 g, 0.3 mmol), (NH4)6Mo7O24·6H2O (0.124 g, 0.1 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol), 4,4‘-bipy (0.047 g, 0.3 mmol), 2,2‘-bipy (0.028 g, 0.2 mmol) ,and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for a half an hour in air. Then the pH was adjusted to 5.5 by dilute ethylenediamine solution. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave 23 mL and kept at 165 °C for 4 days. After the sample was slowly cooled to room temperature, orange crystals were filtered off, washed with distilled water, and dried in a desiccator at room temperature to give a yield of 37.4% based on Mo. Anal. Caled for C50H40O26N10KCu3Mo8:  C, 27.37; H, 1.84; N, 6.39; Cu, 8.69; Mo, 34.98 (%). Found:  C, 27.58; H, 1.89; N, 6.46; Cu, 8.83; Mo, 34.87 (%). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3586 (w), 3099 (w), 3048 (w), 1607 (m), 1572 (w), 1530 (w), 1488 (w), 1467 (w), 1439 (w), 1428 (w), 1414 (m), 1324 (w), 1310 (w), 1244 (w), 1220 (w), 1173 (w), 1155 (w), 1101 (w), 1073 (w), 1014 (m), 989 (m), 970 (m), 953 (m), 922 (s), 878 (m), 789 (s), 734 (w), 672 (w), 651 (w), 573 (w), 529 (m).

A mixture of H3PMo12O40·29H2O (0.191 g, 0.1 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol), 4,4‘-bipy (0.047 g, 0.3 mmol), 2,2‘-bipy (0.028 g, 0.2 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for a half an hour in air. elements.content: X-ray Crystallography. Crystallographic data for 1−3 were all collected at 298 K with a Rigaku R-axis Rapid IP diffractometer using graphite monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710373 Å) and IP technique. The structure was solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 crystallographic software package. Anisotropic thermal parameters were used to refine all non-hydrogen atoms. Carbon-bound hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions; oxygen-bound hydrogen atoms were located in the difference Fourier maps and kept in that position. Further details of the X-ray structural analysis are given in Table .

Synthesis. The successful isolations of compounds 1−3 depend on the exploitation of hydrothermal techniques. Hydrothermal synthesis has recently been proven to be a particularly useful technique in the preparation of organic−inorganic hybrid materials. The exploitation of hydrothermal conditions requires a shift in paradigm from the thermodynamic to the kinetic, such that equilibrium phases are replaced by structurally more complex metastable phases. In the hydrothermal environment, the reduced viscosity of the solvent results in enhanced rates of solvent extraction of solids and crystal growth from solution. Furthermore, since different solubility problems can be minimized, a variety of organic and inorganic precursors can be introduced. However, hydrothermal synthesis is still a relatively complex process because many factors can influence the outcome of reaction, such as the type of initial reactants, starting concentrations, pH values, reaction time, and temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis. The successful isolations of compounds 1-3 depend on the exploitation of hydrothermal techniques. Hydrothermal synthesis has recently been proven to be a particularly useful technique in the preparation of organic-inorganic hybrid materials. The exploitation of hydrothermal conditions requires a shift in paradigm from the thermodynamic to the kinetic, such that equilibrium phases are replaced by structurally more  complex metastable phases. In the hydrothermal environment, the reduced viscosity of the solvent results in enhanced rates of solvent extraction of solids and crystal growth from solution. Furthermore, since different solubility problems can be minimized, a variety of organic and inorganic precursors can be introduced. However, hydrothermal synthesis is still a relatively complex process because many factors can influence the outcome of reaction, such as the type of initial reactants, starting concentrations, pH values, reaction time, and temperature.

elements.content: Parallel experiments showed that the pH value of the reaction system is crucial for the crystallization of compound 1−3:  orange crystals of compound 1 could only be obtained in the pH range 5.0−5.5. At pH range 3.0−5.0, no crystalline phase was formed, and the product was a mixture of green and white powders. And for compound 2, the black crystals could be only obtained in the pH range 3.5−4.5. For compound 3, the dark-red crystals could only be obtained in the pH range 4.5−5.5. However, at pH = 4.2 another compound (Hbipy)4[SiW12O40]·xH2O could be synthesized. In addition, the nature of the divalent transition metal is crucial for the formation of compounds 1−3. We tried to replace CuCl2·H2O with CoCl2·6H2O or NiCl2·6H2O in the synthesis of these three compounds, but no isostructural compounds were obtained. For compound 1, when CuCl2·2H2O was replaced with NiCl2·6H2O, another compound [Ni(2,2‘-bipy)3]2[Mo8O26] reported by our group could be synthesized.

For compound 1, when CuCl2⋅2H2O was replaced with NiCl2⋅6H2O, another compound [Ni(2,2‘-bipy)3]2[Mo8O26] reported by our group could be synthesized.

elements.content: Structure Description. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 is composed of one β-[Mo8O26]4- anion, two [{CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}(4,4‘-bipy){CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}0.5]1.5+ units, and one potassium cation, as shown in Figure . The [Mo8O26]4- cluster, which is built from eight distorted MoO6 edge-shared octahedra, is a typical β-octamolybdate. According to the type of oxygen atoms are divided into four categories:  1.708(6)−1.744(6) Å for Mo−O(t), 1.766(5)−2.347(6) Å for Mo−O(μ2), 1.964(5)−2.372(5) Å for Mo−O(μ3), and 2.181(5)−2.478(5) Å for Mo−O(μ5) bonds, respectively. All these bond lengths are within the normal ranges and in close agreement with those described in the literature.

elements.content: Interestingly, there are two distinct copper atoms that have different coordination environments in [{CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}(4,4‘-bipy){CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}0.5]1.5+ unit, Cu(1) is four-coordinated, defined by two nitrogen atoms from 2,2‘-bipy, a nitrogen atom from 4,4‘-bipy, and a terminal oxygen from the octamolybdate cluster, while the other copper atom Cu(2), residing in a trigonal geometry, is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of 2,2‘-bipy and a nitrogen atom of 4,4‘-bipy. All copper sites exhibit +I oxidation state, confirmed by bond valence sum calculations, which give the values of 1.184 and 1.317 for Cu(1) and Cu(2).

elements.content: The β-[Mo8O26]4- polyoxoanion forms a covalent interaction with two [{CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}(4,4‘-bipy){CuI(2,2‘-bipy)}0.5]1.5+ units via the terminal oxygen atoms of the polyoxoanion with Cu−O distance of 2.383(6) Å.

elements.content: The structure of compound 2 consists of the divalent copper {CuII(2,2‘-bipy)}2+ capped [PMo10 VIMo2 VO40]5- building blocks linked by {Cu(4,4‘-bipy)} n n + linear cationic chains into a novel 2D network. As shown in Figure , the polyoxoanion [PMo10 VIMo2 VO40{CuII(2,2‘-bipy)}]3- consists of a reduced Keggin heteropolyanion [PMo10 VIMo2 VO40]5- and a {Cu(2,2‘-bipy)}2+ fragment. As in other well-known Keggin structures, the highly reduced polyoxoanion is formed from 12 MoO6 octahedra and one PO4 tetrahedron. The P−O distances vary from 1.528(5) to 1.535(5) Å, while the Mo−O distances can be divided into three groups:  Mo−Ot 1.670(5)−1.701(5), Mo−Oe/c 1.828(5)−2.005(5), and Mo−Oa 2.404(5)−2.475(4) Å (Ot:  terminal oxygen atoms, Oe:  bridging oxygen atom in an edge, Oc:  bridging oxygen atom in a corner, Oa:  oxygen atom of the PO4 group). The central PO4 tetrahedron shares its oxygen atoms with four Mo3O13 groups, each of which is made up of three edge-sharing MoO6 octahedra. The Mo3O13 subunits are joined to each other by corner-sharing mode.

As shown in Figure , the polyoxoanion [PMo10 VIMo2 VO40{CuII(2,2‘-bipy)}]3- consists of a reduced Keggin heteropolyanion [PMo10 VIMo2 VO40]5- and a {Cu(2,2‘-bipy)}2+ fragment. The central PO4 tetrahedron shares its oxygen atoms with four Mo3O13 groups, each of which is made up of three edge-sharing MoO6 octahedra. The Mo3O13 subunits are joined to each other by corner-sharing mode.

elements.content: An unusual structural feature of compound 2 is that the Keggin polyoxoanion is capped by one divalent Cu(4) atom through four bridging oxo groups. As for Cu(4), it is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from one 2,2‘-bipy ligand and four bridging oxygen atoms from the Keggin unit with Cu−N distances of 1.990(6)−2.003(6) Å and Cu−O distances of 2.006(4)−2.379(5) Å, respectively. Such a kind of connection mode is often observed between the capping vanadium (IV) atoms and the basic POM part, while it is rare for a divalent transition metal.

As for Cu(4), it is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from one 2,2‘-bipy ligand and four bridging oxygen atoms from the Keggin unit with Cu-N distances of 1.990(6)-2.003(6) Å and Cu-O distances of 2.006(4)-2.379(5) Å, respectively. Such a kind of connection mode is often observed between the capping vanadium (IV) atoms and the basic POM part, while it is rare for a divalent transition metal.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , Cu(1), Cu(2), and Cu(3) form three 1D {Cu(4,4'-bipy)} n n + chains along the a-axis by the connection of 4,4‘-bipy. Furthermore, these chains bridge the polyoxoanions arranged in parallel along the b-axis to form a novel 2D network with Cu−O distances of 2.440(5)−2.500(1) Å, being comparable with those in compound [Cu(en)2(H2O)2][Cu(en)2][{Cu(en)2}3H2W12O42]·15H2O. To the best of our knowledge, compound 2 represents the first example of a 2D structure containing the divalent copper capped polyoxometalate building blocks.

elements.content: Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the four crystallographically unique copper atoms exhibit three different coordination geometries and two different valences copper atoms in compound 2. CuI(1) displays a linear {CuN2} coordination geometry and CuI(2) or CuI(3) shows a distorted tetrahedral {CuN2O2} coordination geometry, while CuII(4) exhibits an octahedral geometry in the form of {CuN2O4} as mentioned above. Valence sum calculations on the Cu sites give the values of 1.059, 1.171, 1.049, and 1.964 for Cu(1), Cu(2), Cu(3), and Cu(4); thus Cu(4) exhibits +II oxidation state, and other copper atoms exhibit +I oxidation state, confirmed by the particular coordination geometries of Cu.

elements.content: It is also striking that compound 2 crystallized in a chiral space group P21. As shown in Figure , the left-handed helical chains, which are generated around the crystallographic 2 1 axis, are composed of the [PMo10 VIMo2 VO40{CuII(2,2'-bipy)}]3- polyoxoanions by short interactions of O38 and O47 from the adjacent polyoxoanions.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray study reveals that the structure of 3 is composed of 1D hybrid zigzag chains linked by {Cu(4,4'-bipy)} n n + chains into 3D framework. The polyoxoanion [SiW12O40]4- is a classical Keggin-type structure, which consists of a central SiO4 tetrahedron surrounded by four vertex-sharing W3O13 trimers that result from the association of three edge-sharing WO6 octahedra. The W−O bonds can be divided into three groups, i.e., W−Ot bonds, W−Oe/c bonds, W−Oa bonds, whose bond distances fall in the ranges 1.660(1)−1.711(1), 1.659(1)−1.935(2), and 2.252(1)−2.510(2) Å, and the mean values are 1.691(8), 1.872(3), and 2.400(9) Å, respectively. These results show that WO6 octahedra of the polyoxoanion are severely distorted due to the influence of the outer coordination environment and further verify the interactions between the polyoxoanions [SiW12O40]4- and copper−organonitrogen coordination polymer. Si−O distances varied between 1.46(2) and 1.70(3) Å, average 1.60(7) Å. Each [SiW12O40]4- polyoxoanion is connected by two {[CuI(2,2‘-bipy)(4,4‘-bipy)0.5]2}2+ units in a zigzag chain (Figure ). Furthermore, the zigzag chains are linked by {Cu(4,4‘-bipy)} n n + chains in a 3D framework via weak Cu−O interactions with the distances of 2.541(5)−2.667(2) Å (Figure ). Valence sum calculations on the Cu sites give the values of 1.393 and 1.274 for Cu(1) and Cu(2), confirmed by the particular coordination environments of Cu(I).

elements.content: FT-IR Spectroscopy. In the IR spectrum of compound 1, the characteristic peaks at 789, 878, 922, and 970 cm-1 are attributed to the MoOt and Mo−Oe/c−Mo vibrations. Comparing the IR spectrum of compound 1 with that of β-[Mo8O26]4- polyoxoanion, it can be observed that the shape of peaks in the range 600−1000 cm-1 is nearly identical to that of β-[Mo8O26]4- except slight shifts of some peaks due to the effect of coordination, which indicates that the polyoxoanion in compound 1 still retains the basic β-[Mo8O26]4- structure. This is in agreement with the result of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. In addition, the characteristic bands at 1414, 1439, 1467, 1488, 1530, and 1607 cm-1 can be regarded as features of the 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy molecules.

This is in agreement with the result of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. In addition, the characteristic bands at 1414, 1439, 1467, 1488, 1530, and 1607 cm-1 can be regarded as features of the 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy molecules.

elements.content: There are four characteristic asymmetric vibrations resulting from heteropolyanions with Keggin structure, namely, νas(MoOt), νas(Mo−Oe), νas(Mo−Oc), and νas(P−Oa). Comparing the IR spectrum of compound 2 with those of α-H3PMo12O40·nH2O, the vibration band of the MoOt bond red-shifted from 975 to 942 cm-1 for compound 2; the peak due to the Mo−Oc−Mo bonds red-shifted from 810 to 809 cm-1; the P−Oa bond vibrations are blue-shifted from 1067 to 1072 cm-1; while the vibration band of Mo−Oe−Mo bonds blue-shifted from 870 to 878 cm-1. These results indicate that the polyoxoanions in compound 2 still retain the basic Keggin structure but are distorted due to the effects of coordination. This is in agreement with the result of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Furthermore, the characteristic bands in the region from 1417 to 1612 cm-1 can be regarded as features of the 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy molecules.

elements.content: In the IR spectrum of compound 3, the characteristic peaks at 789, 816, 960, and 917 cm-1 are attributed to the WOt and W−Oe/c−W and Si−Oa vibrations. Compared to the typical α-Keggin-type heteropolyanion [α-SiW12O40]4-,22 these results indicate that the polyoxoanions in compound 3 are distorted due to the interaction between [SiW12O40]4- and copper-organonitrogen coordination polymer. Additionally, the characteristic bands in the region from 1414 to 1609 cm-1 can be regarded as features of the 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy molecules (Supporting Information Figure S1a−c).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analyses. For compound 1, TGA shows that chemical decomposition starts at 206 °C and ends at 528 °C with the weight loss of 36.27%, equivalent to the loss of organic ligands, 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy (calcd 35.59%). For compound 2, the weight loss of 23.59% from 312 to 548 °C displays the loss of the 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy molecules (calcd 23.13%). Thermogravimetric analysis of compound 3 shows two continuous weight loss steps. The weight loss of 20.49% from 398 to 771 °C is equivalent to the loss of coordinated water (calcd 19.66%) (Supporting Information Figure S2a−c).

elements.content: In summary, we have reported three novel complexes formed by polyoxoanion clusters and copper coordination polymer with mixed 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy ligands. Their successful synthesis not only confirms the advantages of hydrothermal methods in preparing new kinds of structural organic−inorganic hybrid solids but also may suggest a new route to the synthesis of unusual hybrid organic−inorganic materials with mixed organic ligands. Given the variations in the polyoxometalate clusters and transition-metal coordination complex linkers, the scope for the further synthesis of POM-based hybrid materials appears to be very inspiring.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have reported three novel complexes formed by polyoxoanion clusters and copper coordination polymer with mixed 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy ligands. Their successful synthesis not only confirms the advantages of hydrothermal methods in preparing new kinds of structural organic-inorganic hybrid solids but also may suggest a new route to the synthesis of unusual hybrid organic-inorganic materials with mixed organic ligands. Given the variations in the polyoxometalate clusters and transition-metal coordination complex linkers, the scope for the further synthesis of POM-based hybrid materials appears to be very inspiring.

Synthesis of Compound 1 − 3. Synthesis of Compound 1. A mixture of KF (0.017 g, 0.3 mmol), (NH4)6Mo7O24·6H2O (0.124 g, 0.1 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol), 4,4‘-bipy (0.047 g, 0.3 mmol), 2,2‘-bipy (0.028 g, 0.2 mmol) ,and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for a half an hour in air. Then the pH was adjusted to 5.5 by dilute ethylenediamine solution. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave 23 mL and kept at 165 °C for 4 days. After the sample was slowly cooled to room temperature, orange crystals were filtered off, washed with distilled water, and dried in a desiccator at room temperature to give a yield of 37.4% based on Mo. Anal. Caled for C50H40O26N10KCu3Mo8:  C, 27.37; H, 1.84; N, 6.39; Cu, 8.69; Mo, 34.98 (%). Found:  C, 27.58; H, 1.89; N, 6.46; Cu, 8.83; Mo, 34.87 (%). IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3586 (w), 3099 (w), 3048 (w), 1607 (m), 1572 (w), 1530 (w), 1488 (w), 1467 (w), 1439 (w), 1428 (w), 1414 (m), 1324 (w), 1310 (w), 1244 (w), 1220 (w), 1173 (w), 1155 (w), 1101 (w), 1073 (w), 1014 (m), 989 (m), 970 (m), 953 (m), 922 (s), 878 (m), 789 (s), 734 (w), 672 (w), 651 (w), 573 (w), 529 (m).

Synthesis of Compound 2. A mixture of H3PMo12O40·29H2O (0.191 g, 0.1 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol), 4,4‘-bipy (0.047 g, 0.3 mmol), 2,2‘-bipy (0.028 g, 0.2 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for a half an hour in air. Then the pH was adjusted to 3.8 by dilute ethylenediamine solution. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and kept at 165 °C for 4 days. After the sample was slowly cooled to room temperature, black crystals were filtered off, washed with distilled water, and dried in a desiccator at room temperature to give a yield of 42.5% based on Mo. Anal. Caled for C40H32O40N8Cu4PMo12:  C, 17.77; H, 1.19; N, 4.15; Cu, 9.41; P, 1.15; Mo, 42.62 (%). Found:  C, 17.83; H, 1.25; N, 4.29; Cu, 9.59; P, 1.10; Mo, 42.28 (%). Synthesis of Compound 3. A mixture of H4SiW12O40·26H2O (0.334 g, 0.1 mmol), CuCl2·2H2O (0.052 g, 0.3 mmol), 4,4‘-bipy (0.047 g, 0.3 mmol), 2,2‘-bipy (0.028 g, 0.2 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) was stirred for a half an hour in air. Then the pH was adjusted to 5.5 by dilute ethylenediamine solution. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave (23 mL) and kept at 165 °C for 4 days. After the sample was slowly cooled to room temperature, dark-red crystals were filtered off, washed with distilled water, and dried in a desiccator at room temperature to give a yield of 29.8% based on Mo. Anal. Caled for C50H40O44N10Cu4SiW12:  C, 15.12; H, 1.01; N, 3.53; Cu, 6.40; Si, 0.71; W, 55.52 (%). Found:  C, 15.31; H, 1.09; N, 3.64; Cu, 6.58; Si, 0.76; W, 55.18 (%). cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analyses. For compound 1, TGA shows that chemical decomposition starts at 206 °C and ends at 528 °C with the weight loss of 36.27%, equivalent to the loss of organic ligands, 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy (calcd 35.59%). For compound 2, the weight loss of 23.59% from 312 to 548 °C displays the loss of the 4,4‘-bipy and 2,2‘-bipy molecules (calcd 23.13%). Thermogravimetric analysis of compound 3 shows two continuous weight loss steps. The weight loss of 20.49% from 398 to 771 °C is equivalent to the loss of coordinated water (calcd 19.66%) (Supporting Information Figure S2a−c).
